poll_list.title: Ratification Poll for Offboarding Events Core Unit (EVENTS-001) - August 8, 2022

content.content: MIP40c3-SP73: Modify Core Unit Budget (EVENTS-001)  Preamble MIP40c3-SP#: 73 Author(s): @Ippy Contributors: Tags: core-unit, events-001, dai-budget, cu-offboarding Status: Rejected Date Applied: 2022-06-22 Date Ratified:  Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip40c3-spxx-modify-core-unit-budget-for-events-001/15991 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmTNaLnY#vote-breakdown   Sentence Summary MIP40c3-SP73 removes all and any active budgets for the Events Core Unit—Dai or MKR.  Specification  Motivation This Core Unit is authorized to spend $898,150 annually. Events are a “nice to have” and not required for this bear market, particularly considering how Daivinity was executed. Mkr token holders’ money was spent on unknown attendees and no business deals or new hires have been credited to that event. Given current budget constraints, the protocol simply does not accrue value from a core unit whose mission statement is: “To provide the best MakerDAO branded event experience to the crypto & Maker community including industry professionals, influencers, and enthusiasts.” And so this core unit should be granted severance and offboarded. This is part of the list of reforms I laid out here for @rune and plan to pursue.  Core Unit ID EVENTS-001  Budget Implementation On this proposal’s approval: No more Dai will be transferred for the use of this Core Unit, either through streaming or through direct payments. This does not apply to any disbursement included in the Golden Parachute section.  Golden Parachute  Breakdown The suggested offboarding compensation (excluding spend on more events) from this Core Unit was the following:     Item Cost     Legal & Accounting $15,000   Saleries and Compensation $88,336   Total $103,336     Implementation Upon the approval of this offboarding subproposal, a transfer will be made of 103,336 DAI to a wallet or wallets publicly communicated to GovAlpha by the facilitator, @PonJerry

content.content: The feedback was regarding the structure of the core unit, arrangement, and business needs prior to ratification (see below). The issue is that the core unit proposal failed to adequately identify the business needs of Maker along with a budget to meet them. When I say unfortunate, I mean just that. To be clear, Onboarding and then promptly offboarding CU is not okay. It sends the wrong message internally and to our counterparties. Our goal should always be to have successful relationships and to avoid conflict and failure. Conflict and failure mean wasted energy and negative sentiment all around. The due diligence efforts on your initial thread were not just to protect MakerDAO but also the Events CU and staff. Due diligence establishes mutual expectations and helps avoid 180 degree reversals through a well informed and thoughtful analysis. Once a strong and defensible case is made, both sides are protected through understanding. Moving Forward. The appropriate ask by the community could be instead a request to fulfill the original MIP analysis, rather than just offboard the core unit,  the community could ask events to establish a clear strategy and roadmap for what you will actually produce, how it fits into the brand and marketing strategy, and what it would cost. Events could ask for the community to meet them there rather than a complete removal of staff. Another option is to migrate a portion this budget to subcontract through another CU, etc. This would still require similar planning above and a statement of work. Regardless, taking the time now in planning and setting expectations will help avoid misunderstanding in the future. This preparation is to the benefit of every stakeholder.  Prior Feedback and Concern: March 9, 2022    MIP39c2-SP32: Adding Events Core Unit (EVENTS-001)   It seems a bit unorthodox to hire two people full time to do events. Not saying it isn’t a lot of work, simply that, the usual arrangement would be an outside contractor managed by existing CU/ CU budget or a SPF fund. Note, this is the exact structure we see above and used to great success. This approach is a better fit, has more appropriate costs and does not burden the DAO with ongoing obligations. Why fix something that isn’t broken? Core units come with obligations. We just saw the headache of offboarding a core unit, let’s be pragmatic in reviewing core units. Core units are one tool in our toolbox. No need to use a hammer on a screw when we have a screwdriver.   March 10, 2022    MIP39c2-SP32: Adding Events Core Unit (EVENTS-001)   Stick with what works and be positive. We have already seen positive results at a generous and practical spend from your proposed team. It does not make sense for Maker and MKR holders to lock in two full time employees on top of these production budgets. Maker does not yet know its own demand for events. Moving forward, I would suggest continuing to use the SPF framework collaborating with other CU as you have been to great success. There is no evident business case under which this core unit proposal makes sense, especially when considering both the underlying economics and the actual present needs of MakerDAO. Your best bet to succeed is not to ride one early success, but instead to build a track record as a long term, reliable partner of the DAO.   March 11, 2022    MIP39c2-SP32: Adding Events Core Unit (EVENTS-001)   Moving forward. If I were in your place, and I was attached to being a core unit, I would prepare the following proposal:  Identify MakerDAO’s actual events needs (qualitative interviews and quantitative figures from core units, including establishing an actual need from the CU roadmaps, get CU budget commitments on long term spend, etc.); Identify how you could pragmatically meet these needs, what it would take, staff, events, etc, not blank check ceilings and guesstimates; Produce honest and objective market review of comparables to produce similar events from other providers Perform a critical but objective review of the competing proposals. Present a clear over under of your proposal versus competitors as well as the cost benefit in quality, service, etc. Regardless of whether the cost is over/under, describe what MakerDAO gains and loses from your services. Clearly define and acknowledge the cons of your proposal and downsides to the DAO. Prepare a budget that fairly meets MakerDAOs needs based on the above analysis and explains how it may also afford the flexibility a DAO requires.   Business needs come first. If you do the above, it will be a fair deal that naturally makes sense to ratify. You will not need to convince people or be constantly changing numbers, arguing about numbers. The case will be made objectively and factually. As it stands, the main issue is that this proposal has not really demonstrated a need for the products as described. Nobody on this thread has been able to make a clear case for the value of the product (parties) against the significant spend (~$1mm). It seems what is missing may be a fundamental understanding of MakerDAO business needs as well as an acknowledgement of the present market climate.

content.content: Ippy:   How were tickets distributed to the previous Daivinity event? Were they paid, raffled, reserved for VIPs, etc?    They were mostly distributed through Maker contributors/CU members and Twitter.  There is no charge for the tickets.     Ippy:   How many attendees were at the previous Daivinity event? (NB: This is a count at the door, not just tickets given out)    Denver- ~850 Amsterdam- ~400 Attendance targets for events can be found in our CU proposal.  These days there is more demand than available capacity.  Amsterdam we had to turn many away as it was a smaller event.     Ippy:   Do we know who they were? If so, who has that list?    No specific list. but from seeing and talking to who was there it mostly consists of industry professionals.  So employees from Maker and other protocols such as Aave, TrueFi, 1 Inch, Optimism, Compound…etc you name the protocal and they were most likely there.  Industry professional is the target.  We directly distribute tickets to all the main protocols so we generally know which protocols are in attendance.     Ippy:   Did we collect any information such as emails, phone numbers, company affiliations? If so, who will be given access to that valuable information?   Will there be any information collected on attendees (number, identity, how they acquired their tickets, contact information, whether they’re the same attendees as last time, our own people or non-token holders, etc)?    The collection of information has come up a few times so let me address this. We do not collect personal information at these events as we don’t see much benefit from collecting this information and doing such has us run into privacy law issues. To expand on the legal side.  If such a list of information existed we would legally not be able to share it publically or beyond our own internal use.  Since MakerDAO legally does not exist we have a legal entity for the CU.  Any information which is collected is the responsibility of our legal entity and privacy laws do not allow us to disclose this information.  Even to another CU as they operate under a completely separate legal entity. So collecting information and sharing publically or beyond our legal entity will not be done as this would put the CU and its members in a legally compromising position.  Which I will not do.  I hope you understand this position as we have to operate within the legal boundaries of multiple jurisdictions. But hope is not all lost.  The team will be issuing a POAP for the event.  A POAP is a way to track and engage attendees in a way that doesn’t put the CU at legal risk as POAP is completely voluntary and all information is available on-chain.     Ippy:   For the upcoming event, what is the breakdown in how tickets are distributed?    Tickets are split by financial contribution for the upcoming event.  So in Makers case, there will be about 550 tickets reserved for distribution.  The other 550 will be split among our 4 partners for the event and it is up to them to distribute them as they see fit. Makers batch of tickets will be given to various parties such as Maker CU members/facilitators, community members (you just need message @Leggevents to get one), industry professionals/protocols and some reserved for a public release via Twitter (@daivinity).

content.content: @Recognized-Delegates  & @rune please read as there is some important financial information to consider shall this proceed. As a start, the team finds this highly disappointing to have an offboarding posted just shy of 2 months after the ratification vote for onboarding the CU.  As a new CU we think it is a reasonable ask for MKR holders to honour the ratification vote and let the team continue with their mandate.  We view onboarding a CU as a commitment by the DAO to at least see out the fiscal year (baring any fraud or poor performance).  There are real people here that have changed their lives to become FTEs of the DAO as a result of the onboarding vote.  IMO reversing course on a vote sends a poor message. We realize that everyone is very concerned with finances and the bear market.  That is understandable.  While this MIP is framed as a cost savings of 898k (The entire CU budget) this will not be the case and cost savings will be significantly lower. Explanation below. A few factors need to be looked at, such as actual CU spending by September (The earliest offboarding date) and current budget reduction. Current CU Budget The approved budget from May 2022 to May 2023 is 898,150 DAI. Budget Reduction Strategy As presented in our CU proposal one of our strategies for reducing the cost of our CU to the DAO is splitting the cost with other protocols This has so far been a success with the CU’s first official upcoming event at EthCC being split with 4 other partners.  Massive credit to @leggEvents is due here as he has done great work delivering on this promise. This is the approach for all events and will generate revenue for the CU of ~213,000 DAI CU Spend by September 2022 Since the first half of our year is weighted more heavily with events (EthCC: July 19, EthWarsaw: Sept 1, DEVCON Bogota Oct 7-17) by the time an offboarding vote would conclude our estimate of CU spend is ~282,000. Note this includes 78,000 of revenue by that point (EthCC & Eth Warsaw).  Bogota will be 75% paid for as we have to book venues months in advance. This is directly due to demand and competition. The size and popularity of events coinciding with Ethereum conventions are growing making it essential to plan months in advance. Offboarding Cost/Term This is an interesting one since our budget passed before the reworked MIP40 in June, which has a section for offboarding costs and MIP4c2-SP15 (Currently in RFC).  While there is severance listed in this MIP this doesn’t capture everything. While MIP4c2-SP15 is technically not approved the current process is pretty much undefined and essentially leaves a CU open to being rugged by the DAO.  But I guess we ask that MKR holders do NOT do that… From the offboarding MIP amendment and some community members’ posts during content production, the suggested approach is 4 months to unwind.  So this is what we are requesting if this MIP proceeds to a vote.  So my first approach to this is directly to request @ippy to add the following to the MIP if it is to proceed. Alternatively, if this is not added to the MIP then I will raise a signal request to create a 2/3 multisig to hold these funds in the case of offboarding.  This would serve a similar way to the new budget process of offboarding costs, see MIP40c2     Item Cost     Remaining Bogota Cost $35,000   Bogota Contengency (15%of major event budget) $16,500   Legal & Accounting $15,000   Saleries and Compensation $88,336   Total $154,836    The 4-month unwind will consist of the team making the Bogota event the last event.  By offboarding, this event will be ~75 percent already paid for.  Doesn’t make sense to let the costs sink.  The largest conference of the year, why would you not want everyone there talking about Maker? Also included are some legal and accounting costs.  I’m probably in for one hell of an audit in the new year due to running this CU. Contingency has been listed as a return to the DAO as it currently has not been used and is not projected to be drawn from.     Item Cost/Revenue     Origional CU Budget -$898,150   Revenue from Partnerships +$213,000   Contengency +$117,150       Projected CU Spend (1 year term) -$568,000       Spend by September -$282,000   Offboarding Cost -$154,836   September Spend with Offboading Costs -$436,836       DAO COST SAVINGS by offboarding CU in September with 4 months unwind(Projected Budget+Spend+Offboading $131,164    So let’s say my numbers are off by 10 percent in either direction.  Essentially by offboarding this CU the DAO is only saving 118,000 to 144,000. While it has been mentioned that this is low-hanging fruit, is it?  We think everyone knows the need to save but is the best approach blindly swinging an axe?  Budget reductions need to be looked at holistically DAO wide if you want to actually reduce operational costs.  Work with and ask questions to facilitators regarding budgeting and spending.  On our side the team has already put forth a way to reduce our budget by 37 percent With an option to further reduce if things get dire.
